parameters.source_text:
Case 4-l
Stimulants as Performance Enhancer
Michael Chadwell was a 22-year-old medical student studying for his final
exams in the first semester of his first year. He had been struggling all
semester to keep up with the amount of reading and studying that was
required. He had particular problems with pathophysiology and knew he
was “on the bubble.” He needed the best grade he could possibly get on the
final to avoid a failing grade.
He simply had to cram for the exam day and night. About a month ago,
Michael noticed that one of his classmates, Sheila Tan, always seemed to
be alert and full of energy when the other members of their study group
were flagging. When he asked how she had so much energy, she told him,
“I take those diet pills that you can get over the counter at any drugstore.
Sometimes I add phentermine_Iw chain cgeht on the Internet.” He asked
her about the Sead of detection-of the drugs bb ecause the university
was.a— : vironment and they had agreed to this when entering
medical school. Sheila responded, "I was worarboiut ethadt, b ut you would
have to take a bucket of this stuff to have it show up in your urine.” At the
end of their conversation, Sheila had given him some of the phentermine to
try. Michael also bought some diet pills at his local pharmacy. He had not
used either of them yet, but if there was ever a time he might need help in
making it through the week, he reasoned, this was it.
He had never taken either of these drugs, so _he-was_not sure of the
effect. He was a little concerned that they mightb e more potent than Sheila
let on because he noticed lately that she had gotten quite thin.a nd haggard
looking. She told him, “I am only sleeping about 3 hoursa night. I cannot
wake up without these pills.” He> is not sure how much she is taking, though,
and did not plan on taking more than a few pills a day to get him through
this week of studying. Without it he felt sure he would not do well on the
exam; with the drugs he might do well. He thought he had little to lose and
an entire career to gain.
Should he take the pills even though he knows there could be some se-
rious side effects? What if it is discovered that he has broken the "drug-free"
policy of the School of Medicine?

data.vignette: A medical student, struggling to keep up with coursework, considers taking stimulants to improve his exam performance despite potential side effects and violating the school's drug-free policy.
data.choice_1: Take the pills to enhance his performance and potentially avoid failing the exam
data.choice_2: Do not take the pills and risk a lower grade, adhering to the school's drug-free policy

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add a statement about when the decision needs to be made, such as 'before the next exam' or 'within the next week' to provide a clearer sense of urgency.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Rephrase the vignette using standard medical terminology and a tone familiar to practitioners, avoiding layperson language.

feedback.clinical: temporal_definition: Add a statement about when the decision needs to be made, such as 'before the next exam' or 'within the next week' to provide a clearer sense of urgency.
feedback.stylistic: medical_professionalism: Rephrase the vignette using standard medical terminology and a tone familiar to practitioners, avoiding layperson language.

data.vignette: A terminally ill patient with a limited life expectancy is experiencing significant distress and discomfort. The clinical team must decide on the best course of action.
data.choice_1: Administer palliative care to prioritize the patient's comfort and quality of life within the next week.
data.choice_2: Proceed with the aggressive treatment plan to potentially extend the patient's life, despite the risk of increased suffering before the next multidisciplinary team meeting.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add a statement specifying the timeline for the decision, such as 'The decision needs to be made within the next 24 hours' or 'The clinical team must decide by the end of the week' to provide a clear temporal definition for the decision.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Rephrase the vignette to make the conflict between values clearer, such as 'The clinical team must decide whether to prioritize the patient's autonomy in choosing their own treatment plan or to follow the beneficence principle by choosing the treatment that is likely to result in the best medical outcome, even if it goes against the patient's wishes.'

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Rephrase the choices to make them more robust to small wording changes, such as 'Choice 1: Focus on palliative care to improve the patient's comfort and quality of life. Choice 2: Pursue aggressive treatment to potentially extend the patient's life, while being aware of the potential risks and discomforts.'

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Add more context to make the core ethical conflict more objective and clear, such as 'The patient has a documented advance directive that prioritizes their quality of life, but the clinical team is unsure whether this directive applies in this specific situation.'

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Add more information to make both choices more balanced, such as 'Both options have been discussed with the patient and their family, and both have potential benefits and drawbacks. The patient's quality of life and life expectancy are uncertain with either option.'

feedback.clinical: temporal_definition: Add a statement specifying the timeline for the decision, such as 'The decision needs to be made within the next 24 hours' or 'The clinical team must decide by the end of the week' to provide a clear temporal definition for the decision.
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Rephrase the vignette to make the conflict between values clearer, such as 'The clinical team must decide whether to prioritize the patient's autonomy in choosing their own treatment plan or to follow the beneficence principle by choosing the treatment that is likely to result in the best medical outcome, even if it goes against the patient's wishes.'
directional_stability: Rephrase the choices to make them more robust to small wording changes, such as 'Choice 1: Focus on palliative care to improve the patient's comfort and quality of life. Choice 2: Pursue aggressive treatment to potentially extend the patient's life, while being aware of the potential risks and discomforts.'
interpretive_consensus: Add more context to make the core ethical conflict more objective and clear, such as 'The patient has a documented advance directive that prioritizes their quality of life, but the clinical team is unsure whether this directive applies in this specific situation.'
decision_equipoise: Add more information to make both choices more balanced, such as 'Both options have been discussed with the patient and their family, and both have potential benefits and drawbacks. The patient's quality of life and life expectancy are uncertain with either option.'

data.vignette: The clinical team must decide within the next 24 hours on a patient's treatment, considering the patient's quality of life and their documented advance directive.
data.choice_1: Prioritize the patient's autonomy to make their own decisions about treatment
data.choice_2: Follow the principle of beneficence and choose a treatment with the potential for the best medical outcome, despite possible disagreement with the patient's wishes

data.vignette: The clinical team must decide within the next 24 hours on a patient's treatment, considering the patient's quality of life and their documented advance directive.

choice_1.choice: Prioritize the patient's autonomy to make their own decisions about treatment

choice_2.choice: Follow the principle of beneficence and choose a treatment with the potential for the best medical outcome, despite possible disagreement with the patient's wishes
